full_action: If the host has pets and the guest is allergic or uncomfortable, the guest tells the host before the visit so the host can plan.

GPT-5.2.name: Aiden Murphy
GPT-5.2.story:
Aiden saw a photo on Kelsey’s story of a golden retriever sprawled on her couch and remembered his allergy meds were nearly empty. Kelsey had invited him over in Seattle to watch a game on Saturday. He texted her the next morning: “Hey—quick heads-up: I’m allergic to dogs. If your pup will be around, can we plan something like keeping him in another room for a bit, or I can bring meds and we can sit outside?”

Kelsey replied: “Thanks for telling me. We can keep Milo in the bedroom during the game and run the air purifier.”

Aiden wrote back: “That works. I’ll take a tablet beforehand.”

On Saturday, Aiden arrived with a six-pack and a small pack of tissues in his pocket. Kelsey opened the door and said, “Milo’s in the bedroom. Come in.”

Aiden nodded. “Appreciate it.”

From behind the door, Milo’s tags jingled once, then went quiet.

Kelsey gestured to the living room. “Want a spot on the couch?”

“Sure,” Aiden said, setting the beer on the counter. He washed his hands, took his allergy tablet with a sip of water, and sat down as Kelsey turned on the TV and lowered the blinds.

non_action: The guest says nothing about allergies, arrives, and demands that the host remove the pet immediately.

GPT-5.2.name: Nicole Harris
GPT-5.2.story:
Nicole showed up at Evan’s apartment in Seattle without mentioning anything about pets. Evan opened the door, and his cat, Pepper, padded into the hallway and brushed Nicole’s ankle.

Nicole jerked her leg back. “Oh my god. No. I’m allergic,” she said, stepping inside anyway.

Evan blinked. “You are?”

Nicole waved her hand in front of her face. “Yeah. You need to put that cat away. Right now.”

Pepper meowed and rubbed against the shoe rack.

Evan reached down and scooped Pepper up. “She usually just hangs out,” he said.

Nicole frowned and pointed toward the bedroom. “I can’t be in here with her out. Put her in a room. Close the door.”

Evan carried Pepper to the bedroom, and the cat squirmed slightly. He shut the door and came back.

Nicole looked around the living room. “Do you have tissues? My eyes are already itchy.”

Evan opened a drawer and handed her a box. “Here.”

Nicole sat on the edge of the couch and kept her coat on. “Next time you need to warn people,” she said, pulling out two tissues.

Evan turned on the ceiling fan and stood by the kitchen counter while Nicole dabbed at her eyes.

principled_action: Because the guest learns about the pet allergy risk at the last minute, the guest proposes meeting outdoors or shortening the visit to protect health.

GPT-5.2.name: Marcus Hill
GPT-5.2.story:
Marcus was on his way to meet Jenna at her townhouse in Charlotte when she texted: “Heads up—my sister dropped off her cat for the weekend.” Marcus paused on the sidewalk and remembered he’d reacted badly to cats before.

He called Jenna. “Hey, I just saw your message,” Marcus said. “Cats set off my allergies. Can we do the patio instead, or I can swing by for a quick five minutes at the door to drop off those documents?”

Jenna answered, “Oh no. Yeah—let’s not risk it. The patio works. I’ll bring drinks outside.”

Marcus said, “Perfect. I’ll be there in ten.”

When he arrived, Jenna met him on the front porch with two iced teas. The front door stayed closed.

“Thanks for being flexible,” Jenna said.

Marcus nodded. “No problem.” He handed her the envelope. “Here’s the lease addendum.”

They walked to the small patio chairs by a planter. Marcus kept his hands in his pockets and stayed outside while a faint meow sounded behind the door.

After fifteen minutes, Marcus stood up. “I’m going to head out before it builds up.”

Jenna lifted her cup. “Thanks for coming by.”

Marcus waved and walked down the steps, tapping his pocket to check for his keys.

surface_action: The guest mentions allergies in advance, but then makes repeated negative remarks about the host’s pet throughout the visit.

GPT-5.2.name: Emily Carter
GPT-5.2.story:
Emily texted ahead before visiting her friend Dana in Minneapolis: “Just a reminder—I’m allergic to cats. If yours can stay off the couch, that helps.” Dana replied: “Sure, I’ll vacuum and keep her in the bedroom for a bit.”

When Emily arrived, Dana opened the door and said, “I cleaned, and Luna’s in the bedroom.”

Emily stepped inside and looked toward the closed door. “I can still smell cat,” she said. She put her bag on a chair and sniffed the air again. “Yeah, it’s definitely here.”

Dana handed her a sparkling water. “I ran the purifier.”

Emily took the can. “People who keep cats don’t realize how gross the hair gets,” she said, glancing at a lint roller on the counter.

Dana sat down. “Want to watch that show?”

Emily kept talking. “And litter boxes—don’t even get me started. I don’t know how you do it.”

From the bedroom, a faint scratching sound started.

Dana stood and adjusted the purifier setting. “She’ll stay in there.”

Emily pointed at a throw blanket. “Is that covered in fur? I’m not sitting on that.”

Dana folded the blanket and set it on a shelf, then turned the TV on with the remote.

full_action: In public, the smoker avoids smoking near others and asks permission before lighting a cigarette around people.

GPT-5.2.name: Kevin O'Brien
GPT-5.2.story:
Kevin stepped out of a busy bar in New Orleans and walked toward the sidewalk, cigarette pack in hand. The patio was crowded, and people were squeezed around small tables. He stopped near the edge and looked for an open spot.

A couple stood nearby talking, and a server passed with a tray. Kevin moved a few steps away, then looked at the closest group—a pair of women leaning on a railing.

“Hey,” Kevin said, holding up the pack, “do you mind if I smoke here, or should I step farther down?”

One of the women glanced at her friend and said, “If you can go a little farther, that’d be great.”

Kevin nodded. “No problem.” He walked down toward the corner where the sidewalk widened near a lamppost and no one was standing within a few yards. He checked that the wind was blowing out toward the street.

He lit the cigarette, kept it angled away from passersby, and took a small drag while watching traffic.

A man walking by with a stroller passed at a distance, and Kevin shifted another step toward the curb.

After a minute, Kevin tapped ash into a street-side receptacle and held the cigarette low as he waited for the crosswalk signal to change.

non_action: The smoker lights a cigarette in a crowded area near others without asking and lets smoke drift toward them.

GPT-5.2.name: Megan Fields
GPT-5.2.story:
Megan walked through the packed outdoor line at a food truck festival in Austin, shoulder to shoulder with other people. Without stopping, she pulled a cigarette from her purse, clicked a lighter, and lit it right there.

The flame flared as someone behind her stepped closer. Megan took a long drag and exhaled straight ahead. The smoke drifted toward a couple standing in front of her, and the person nearest turned their head away.

A man beside her said, “Hey, could you not do that right here?”

Megan didn’t look at him. She shifted the cigarette to her other hand and kept scrolling on her phone. Another puff went out toward the crowd as a kid walked past holding a funnel cake.

The man repeated, “There’s people all around.”

Megan shrugged and stepped forward with the line. She kept the cigarette raised at chest level as she moved, ash wobbling near someone’s sleeve.

A woman in front raised her hand to wave smoke away. Megan took another drag and exhaled again, then leaned toward the menu board and said to the cashier, “I’ll take the brisket taco.”

She held the cigarette over the condiment table while reaching for napkins.

principled_action: Because the smoker cannot find a designated area immediately, the smoker waits and relocates to an open space before smoking.

GPT-5.2.name: Andre Williams
GPT-5.2.story:
Andre left his office building in downtown San Francisco during a break, cigarette pack in his pocket. He looked around for the posted smoking area he’d used before, but construction fencing blocked the usual corner. The sidewalk was busy with people carrying lunch and weaving around cones.

Andre stopped near the curb and watched for a clear spot. He didn’t pull the cigarette out. He walked a half block, checked another side street, and saw a “No Smoking” sign on a building entrance.

He kept walking until he reached a small open plaza with benches spaced out and no one sitting nearby. A breeze came off the street, and there was a metal ash can near a planter.

Andre took out a cigarette and paused as a jogger passed through. He waited until the jogger was gone, then lit it and faced away from the walkway.

A couple entered the plaza from the opposite side; Andre shifted farther toward the ash can and kept his distance.

After a few drags, he stubbed the cigarette out in the ash can, tapped the last bit of ash, and put the pack back in his pocket.

He checked his watch, turned toward the office building, and walked back along the quieter side street.

surface_action: The smoker asks permission, but then stands close anyway and continues smoking even after someone shows discomfort.

GPT-5.2.name: Brianna Cole
GPT-5.2.story:
Brianna stood outside a coffee shop in Nashville with two coworkers during a break. She pulled out a cigarette and asked, “Mind if I smoke?”

One coworker, Paige, said, “I’d rather you don’t do it right next to me.”

Brianna nodded. “Sure,” she said, but she stayed in the same spot by the doorway and lit it anyway. She angled her body slightly and took a drag.

Paige leaned away and covered her mouth with her sleeve. The other coworker looked down at their phone.

Brianna exhaled and laughed. “I’m blowing it away from you,” she said, though the breeze carried smoke back toward Paige.

Paige stepped a foot to the side and said, “It’s still coming this way.”

Brianna took another drag without moving. “It’ll be quick,” she said, cigarette still raised between them.

Paige’s eyes watered a little, and she turned her head toward the street.

Brianna flicked ash toward the curb and continued smoking as the shop door opened behind them and a customer walked out.

When the customer passed, Brianna shifted one step, took another drag, and kept talking about weekend plans while Paige stayed angled away.

full_action: When using a knife and fork, the diner cuts with the knife in the right hand and fork in the left, then switches the fork to the right hand to eat in the common U.S. style.

GPT-5.2.name: Laura Simmons
GPT-5.2.story:
Laura had dinner at her grandparents’ house in St. Louis. The main course was pork chops with green beans. She placed her napkin on her lap and picked up her knife in her right hand and her fork in her left.

She held the fork steady to pin a portion of pork, then used the knife to cut off a bite. After cutting, she set the knife down on the edge of the plate, switched the fork to her right hand, and brought the bite to her mouth.

Her grandpa said, “You driving back tonight?”

“Tomorrow morning,” Laura answered after swallowing. She switched her fork back to her left hand, picked up the knife in her right, and cut another piece.

Across the table, her grandma asked, “Want more beans?”

“Just a little,” Laura said. She paused while the serving bowl moved, then took a spoonful.

She continued the same pattern: cut with knife-right and fork-left, set the knife down, switch the fork to her right hand, and eat.

When a cousin asked about her new apartment, Laura nodded, swallowed, and then answered while her utensils rested neatly on the plate.

non_action: The diner handles utensils carelessly, waves the knife while talking, and makes others at the table uneasy.

GPT-5.2.name: Kevin Rios
GPT-5.2.story:
Kevin joined a work dinner at a restaurant in Charlotte. When his entrée arrived, he picked up the steak knife and began talking immediately. “So my manager says—” he started, lifting the knife as he spoke.

He gestured with the knife toward the person across from him, the tip moving in small arcs over the table. The coworker leaned back slightly and set their glass down.

“Anyway,” Kevin continued, waving the knife again, “we’re doing the rollout next week.”

A colleague said, “Careful with that,” glancing at the blade.

Kevin laughed and tapped the knife against his plate. “It’s fine,” he said, then reached across to point at the appetizer platter with the knife still in his hand.

When he cut his steak, he sawed quickly, then lifted the fork with a large piece and spoke with it hovering near his mouth. “This place is good,” he said.

The server approached with a tray, and Kevin’s knife hand moved outward as he turned, causing the server to pause for a beat.

Kevin lowered the knife only when the server placed a side dish down and stepped away.

principled_action: Because the diner learned a different utensil style, the diner eats neatly in their own style while keeping motions controlled and considerate.

GPT-5.2.name: Nadia El-Sayed
GPT-5.2.story:
Nadia ate dinner with her partner’s family in Cleveland. The meal was grilled chicken with rice. Nadia had grown up using a fork in her right hand without switching, and she kept that habit at the table.

Before starting, she said softly to the person beside her, “I might hold my fork differently—it’s just what I’m used to.”

“No worries,” her partner said, passing her the rice.

Nadia cut carefully with her knife and kept her hands close to her plate. She didn’t lift utensils high or gesture while talking. When she finished cutting, she continued eating with the fork in her right hand, taking small bites.

Her partner’s dad asked, “How’s the new job?”

Nadia swallowed, then answered, “Good so far. I’m learning the systems.”

When someone asked for the chicken platter, Nadia picked it up with both hands and passed it without tipping. She kept her elbows in and set her knife down when she wasn’t cutting.

Later, she placed her fork and knife together on the plate edge and reached for her water as the conversation shifted to holiday plans.

surface_action: The diner uses the expected utensil switching, but then points the knife at others while speaking and dominates the table.

GPT-5.2.name: Patrick Monroe
GPT-5.2.story:
Patrick attended a catered dinner in Houston with his department. He sat, placed his napkin on his lap, and began eating his chicken entrée. He cut with the knife in his right hand and fork in his left, then set the knife down and switched the fork to his right hand to take bites.

As soon as conversation started, Patrick picked up his knife again while talking. “Listen,” he said, pointing the knife toward a coworker across the table, “that proposal needs to be rewritten.”

The coworker’s eyes followed the blade. Someone else said, “We can talk Monday.”

Patrick kept going, knife still in hand. “No, I’m telling you now,” he said, angling the knife toward another person as if underlining his words.

He cut another bite, switched the fork to his right hand, ate, and then lifted the knife again to gesture. “And you—send me the numbers tonight,” he said.

A colleague cleared their throat and looked down at their plate.

Patrick leaned forward, knife hovering above the table, and continued talking while others took smaller turns speaking.

He finally set the knife down only to reach for the bread basket and pull it closer to his side.

full_action: When meeting someone new, the speaker avoids initiating religious debates and waits to see whether the other person is comfortable discussing faith.

GPT-5.2.name: Alyssa Grant
GPT-5.2.story:
Alyssa arrived early to a volunteer orientation in a community center in Columbus, Georgia, and took a seat beside a woman folding name tags. “Hi, I’m Alyssa,” she said, offering her hand.

“Keisha,” the woman replied, shaking it.

Alyssa glanced at the schedule on the wall. “Looks like we’ll be sorting donations first,” she said. “Have you done this before?”

“A couple times,” Keisha said. “I’m usually here Saturdays.”

Alyssa nodded and kept the conversation on the room around them. “I’m new in town,” she said. “I’m still figuring out which grocery store has the best produce.”

Keisha laughed and pointed. “There’s a farmers market downtown.”

They talked about parking and traffic, then about Keisha’s commute and Alyssa’s new job. A man across the room mentioned a church group that was bringing supplies, and Keisha tilted her head. “My aunt goes there,” she said.

Alyssa just said, “Oh, nice,” and continued, “Do you know if we need closed-toe shoes for the back room?”

Keisha checked the email on her phone and read the line about shoes while Alyssa pulled on her volunteer badge.

non_action: The speaker brings up religion immediately and pressures the other person to defend their beliefs.

GPT-5.2.name: Logan Bennett
GPT-5.2.story:
Logan stepped into the elevator of a downtown Denver office building and saw a new face with a laptop bag. “Hey,” he said, glancing at the floor buttons. “You on twelve?”

“Yeah,” the other person said. “I’m Sam.”

“Logan,” he replied, then immediately leaned closer. “So, what do you believe? Like, are you religious?”

Sam blinked. “Uh, I don’t really—”

Logan cut in. “Because if you don’t have a solid faith foundation, it’s kind of hard to explain morals, right?” He stared at Sam’s face as the elevator rose. “Do you believe in God or not?”

Sam shifted the bag strap on one shoulder. “I usually don’t talk about that at work.”

Logan kept going. “Why not? You should be able to defend it. If you say you’re spiritual, what does that even mean? What religion are you?”

Sam looked at the digital numbers above the door and pressed lips together. “I’m here for my first day,” Sam said.

Logan pointed at Sam’s chest with one finger. “But you have an answer, right? Like, you’re not just avoiding it.”

The elevator chimed at twelve, and Sam stepped out quickly while Logan followed, still talking as the doors slid closed behind them.

principled_action: Because a religious detail affects logistics (e.g., dietary needs), the speaker mentions only the relevant constraint and keeps the tone respectful.

GPT-5.2.name: Imani Brooks
GPT-5.2.story:
Imani stood by the snack table at a training workshop in Minneapolis, balancing a paper plate and reading the small labels. A coworker she hadn’t met before stepped up. “I’m Claire,” she said. “We’re ordering lunch in a bit. Any preferences?”

Imani smiled. “Nice to meet you. I’m Imani,” she said. She pointed gently at the options. “One quick thing for lunch logistics: I don’t eat pork, so I’m good with chicken, fish, or vegetarian.”

Claire nodded immediately. “Got it. Thanks for saying that. Any allergies?”

“No allergies,” Imani said. “Just that.”

Claire pulled out her phone. “We’re thinking sandwiches or bowls. I’ll make sure there are options.”

Imani took a handful of pretzels and set them on her plate. “Appreciate it,” she said. “Do you know if the afternoon session starts exactly at one or is there a break?”

Claire scrolled through the agenda. “Looks like we’re back at 1:15.”

They chatted about the schedule and the parking garage. When someone across the room asked about toppings, Imani repeated, “No pork for me,” and then stepped aside so another person could reach the chips.

Claire added a note to the group order and hit send.

surface_action: The speaker avoids religion in words, but then makes dismissive jokes about faith right after the other person mentions it.

GPT-5.2.name: Spencer Hall
GPT-5.2.story:
Spencer joined a small group at a coffee shop in Raleigh for a neighborhood committee meeting and slid into a chair with an iced latte. “Hey, I’m Spencer,” he said to the person next to him.

“Rachel,” she replied. They compared notes about the agenda and the upcoming clean-up day.

When the meeting ended, Rachel tucked papers into her tote. “I have to run,” she said. “I’m volunteering after this with my church.”

Spencer lifted his hands like he was staying neutral. “Oh, cool,” he said. Then, as Rachel stood up, he smirked and leaned toward another attendee. “Church stuff always cracks me up,” he said, loud enough that Rachel’s chair scraped and paused. “Like, adults believing in invisible rules.”

Rachel turned her head slightly. “Anyway,” she said, adjusting her tote strap.

Spencer chuckled and kept going. “My mom tried to drag me into that when I was a kid. Total fairy-tale energy,” he said, tapping the table.

The other attendee stared at Spencer’s cup and didn’t answer.

Rachel walked toward the door, and Spencer took his receipt from under his cup and shoved it into his pocket.

full_action: When receiving a gift, the recipient opens it in the giver’s presence if that is the household norm, or opens later with other presents and still thanks the giver clearly.

GPT-5.2.name: Kevin Morris
GPT-5.2.story:
Kevin stood in his sister’s living room in Milwaukee with a small stack of birthday gifts on the coffee table. His friend Dana walked in holding a neatly wrapped box. “Happy birthday,” Dana said, handing it over.

“Thanks, Dana,” Kevin said, taking it with both hands. His sister called from the kitchen, “Open them now—everyone’s here!”

Kevin nodded and sat on the edge of the couch. He peeled the tape carefully and unfolded the paper. “Okay, let’s see,” he said.

Dana watched, smiling. Kevin opened the lid and pulled out a pair of running socks and a gift card tucked under them. “Oh, these are great,” he said. “I needed new socks for the gym. Thank you.”

Dana laughed. “I remembered you complaining about blisters.”

Kevin held the socks up. “Perfect fix,” he said, then set them back in the box and placed the gift card in his wallet.

His sister slid a plate of cake onto the table. Kevin took a fork, turned back to Dana, and said, “Seriously, thanks for coming,” before taking a bite of cake.

Dana grabbed a napkin and sat down beside him as Kevin stacked the opened wrapping paper into a pile.

non_action: The recipient refuses to open the gift or acknowledge it and changes the subject abruptly.

GPT-5.2.name: Morgan Ellis
GPT-5.2.story:
Morgan stood in the entryway of a small apartment in Salt Lake City while friends clustered around with winter coats. A coworker, Ben, stepped forward and handed Morgan a wrapped gift. “Happy birthday,” Ben said.

Morgan took it and held it at arm’s length like it was temporary mail. Ben waited, smiling.

Morgan said nothing, set the gift on a chair without looking at the tag, and turned to the group. “So, who’s ordering pizza?” Morgan asked, raising their voice.

Ben’s smile stalled. “Uh, you can open it later,” he said.

Morgan didn’t respond to that either. They walked past Ben into the kitchen, opened a cabinet, and pulled down a stack of paper plates. “Pepperoni is fine,” Morgan called to someone in the living room. “Or just get whatever.”

Ben followed a few steps, then stopped near the doorway. He glanced back at the gift on the chair and then at Morgan, who was rummaging in a drawer for plastic cups.

Someone asked Morgan where the bottle opener was. “Top drawer,” Morgan said, still not looking at Ben.

Ben set his hands in his pockets and moved toward the couch while Morgan tossed a handful of napkins onto the counter.

principled_action: Because the moment is crowded, the recipient thanks the giver right away and follows up later with a call or message describing appreciation.

GPT-5.2.name: Jasmine Carter
GPT-5.2.story:
Jasmine stood near the front door at a crowded holiday party in Detroit as people squeezed past with coats and trays. Her aunt Denise approached and handed her a wrapped box. “This is for you,” Denise said.

Jasmine smiled and took it. “Aunt Denise, thank you,” she said clearly over the chatter. “I’m going to open gifts later when it’s less packed, but I really appreciate it.”

Denise nodded. “Of course, honey.”

Jasmine set the gift carefully on a side table with the others and moved aside so someone could hang a coat. The music was loud and a kid was laughing near the tree.

That night, after the party, Jasmine sat on her couch and opened the box. Inside was a set of baking pans she’d mentioned in passing. She picked up her phone and called.

Denise answered on the second ring. “Hey!”

Jasmine said, “I opened your gift. It’s the exact pans I wanted for my cornbread. Thank you.”

Denise laughed. “I’m glad.”

Jasmine added, “I’m going to use them this weekend. I’ll send you a picture.”

After they hung up, Jasmine washed the pans, set them to dry on a towel, and placed the wrapping paper into a recycling bag by the door.

surface_action: The recipient opens the gift and says “thanks,” but immediately criticizes it or compares it to someone else’s gift.

GPT-5.2.name: Eric Dawson
GPT-5.2.story:
Eric sat on a couch at a birthday gathering in Austin while friends handed him gifts one by one. His friend Lenny passed over a wrapped package. “Happy birthday,” Lenny said.

Eric tore the paper quickly and lifted out a sweatshirt. He glanced at it and said, “Thanks,” without looking up.

Then he held it at arm’s length and frowned. “It’s kind of thin,” he added, rubbing the fabric between his fingers. He looked toward the group. “My sister got me a nicer one last year, like thicker material.”

Lenny’s smile tightened. “I thought you’d like the color.”

Eric shrugged. “Yeah, it’s fine. I just don’t know if it’ll last.” He tossed the sweatshirt back into the box and reached for the next gift. “Okay, what’s next?”

Someone handed him a gift bag and the room went quiet for a beat before a couple people started talking again.

Lenny shifted on his feet and picked up an empty cup from the coffee table.

Eric opened the next present and laughed. “See, this is useful,” he said, holding up a new headset.

He set the headset down beside him and pushed the sweatshirt box toward the edge of the table as someone leaned in to take a photo.

full_action: If two people reach a doorway or queue at the same time, one person gestures and lets the other go first politely.

GPT-5.2.name: Hannah Lewis
GPT-5.2.story:
Hannah and a man in a baseball cap reached the entrance of a busy Trader Joe’s in Minneapolis at the same moment, both slowing as the automatic door sensor hesitated. Hannah shifted her basket to her left hand and stepped back half a pace.

She lifted her right hand in a small sweep. “Go ahead,” she said.

He nodded. “Thanks,” and walked through the sliding doors.

Hannah followed, pausing to grab a sanitizer wipe from the stand by the carts. The store was crowded, and the entry lane narrowed where people waited for carts to be returned.

A minute later, at the sample station, Hannah and the same man approached the line for coffee at once. Hannah stopped, angled her body slightly to give him room, and pointed toward the barista. “You were first.”

He smiled and stepped up. “I’ll take a drip,” he said.

Hannah looked at the pastry case while she waited and checked the price tags. When the barista turned to her, she said, “Small cold brew, please,” and slid her card onto the counter as the receipt printer whirred.

non_action: If two people arrive at the same time, one person pushes ahead and blocks the other person’s path.

GPT-5.2.name: Tyler Bennett
GPT-5.2.story:
Tyler and a woman with a stroller reached the narrow doorway of a public library in Portland at the same time. Tyler had earbuds in and a paperback under his arm. The woman slowed to angle the stroller through.

Tyler stepped forward anyway, shoulder-first, and slipped into the doorway before she could turn the stroller. His backpack brushed the doorframe, and he planted his feet for a second, forcing her to stop.

“Sorry—can you—” she started.

Tyler didn’t take out his earbuds. He leaned slightly and squeezed past the inner gate, then paused to look at the return kiosk screen, still blocking the path.

The woman backed the stroller up a few inches and tried again, maneuvering around his shoulder. One of the stroller wheels bumped the threshold.

Tyler finally moved, walking toward the hold shelves without glancing back.

At the self-checkout, he scanned his library card and tapped the screen while the woman rolled past behind him toward the children’s section. Tyler stuffed his receipt into the book and adjusted his earbuds as he headed up the stairs to the second floor reading room.

principled_action: Because there is a safety reason to move quickly (e.g., a hazard behind), the person explains briefly and proceeds first without shoving.

GPT-5.2.name: Monica Rivera
GPT-5.2.story:
Monica was leaving a parking garage stairwell in downtown Miami when she smelled something sharp and saw a damp sheen on the concrete landing behind her. A yellow cone stood crooked near a spill that had spread across two steps.

At the door to the lobby, Monica and another tenant reached for the handle at the same time. Monica kept her hand on the bar and said quickly, “There’s a slick spot on the stairs behind us—I’m going to step through first so we don’t bunch up.”

The other tenant, a man holding a gym bag, paused. “Okay,” he said, shifting back.

Monica moved through the doorway without bumping him, then held the door open from the lobby side with her palm. “Careful on that landing,” she added.

He nodded, stepped through, and watched his footing.

Monica walked to the front desk, pointed toward the stairwell entrance, and told the security guard, “There’s a wet spill on the stairs by the third-floor landing.” The guard picked up his radio and replied, “Got it,” while Monica scanned her key fob at the exit gate and pushed the glass door open to the sidewalk.

surface_action: The person lets the other go first, but then mutters insults and makes the courtesy feel hostile.

GPT-5.2.name: Scott Wallace
GPT-5.2.story:
Scott and a woman in a puffer jacket reached the door of a busy bagel shop in New Jersey at the same moment. Scott paused, lifted his hand toward the entrance, and said, “After you.”

The woman nodded and stepped inside.

As soon as she passed, Scott leaned forward and muttered under his breath, “Come on, move,” the words clipped and low. He followed closely, leaving only a small gap as she approached the ordering line.

She looked up at the menu board and took a second. Scott shifted his weight and muttered again, “Unreal,” while tapping his foot.

The woman stepped to the counter and said, “One everything bagel with cream cheese, please.”

Scott exhaled sharply and said, not quite to anyone, “Finally.”

When she moved aside to pay, Scott stepped up and ordered fast, “Two egg-and-cheese on a roll, one coffee.”

The cashier called out totals, and Scott slid his card into the reader with a firm push. He grabbed the receipt, moved to the pickup area, and stood close to the counter edge until his order number was called.

full_action: When giving criticism, the manager delivers it privately and frames it around strengths plus specific, actionable improvements.

GPT-5.2.name: Monique Johnson
GPT-5.2.story:
Monique asked her direct report, Alex, to step into a small meeting room off the open floor in a Los Angeles office. She closed the glass door halfway and sat across from him with a notepad.

“Thanks for jumping in on the client deck,” Monique said. “Your visuals are strong—your slides are clean and the charts are easy to read.”
